channel.title: Find the magic number! (it's way to hard for me!)
channel.description:
I need to find a number which goes in 7104 and 3087. The same number must also go in 6208 and 3496. (only by division/multiplication)
I got mind blown trying to work it out but if anybody here is smart enough to work it I'd love you forever! Would appreciate it a lot!

item.title: Find the magic number! (it's way to hard for me!)
item.dc:creator: @eyeownyew Eyeownyew
item.description:
@eyeownyew wrote:

[quote=“Ambokile, post:16, topic:517443”][code=Java]static double[] numbers = { 7104, 3087, 6208, 3496 };
static boolean[] works = new boolean[numbers.length];

public static void main(String[] args)
{
	for (int i = 0; i <= 710500; i++) {
		double f = (i / 100.0);
		for (int n = 0; n < numbers.length; n++) {
			if (numbers[n] % f == 0)
				works[n] = true;
		}
		if (works[0] && works[1] && works[2] && works[3])
			System.out.println("The number " + f + " works!");
		for (int j = 0; j < works.length; j++)
			works[j] = false;
	}
}[/code]

Output:

[quote]The number 0.25 works!
The number 0.5 works!
The number 1.0 works![/quote]

I divided by 100 to prevent this: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/5257166/java-floats-and-doubles-how-to-avoid-that-0-0-0-1-0-1-0-9000001[/quote] I was only looking for integer solutions, as there are infinite decimal solutions

Read full topic
item.source: Find the magic number! (it's way to hard for me!)

item.title: Find the magic number! (it's way to hard for me!)
item.dc:creator: @Ambokile Ambokile
item.description:
@Ambokile wrote:

[code=Java]static double[] numbers = { 7104, 3087, 6208, 3496 };
static boolean[] works = new boolean[numbers.length];

public static void main(String[] args)
{
	for (int i = 0; i <= 710500; i++) {
		double f = (i / 100.0);
		for (int n = 0; n < numbers.length; n++) {
			if (numbers[n] % f == 0)
				works[n] = true;
		}
		if (works[0] && works[1] && works[2] && works[3])
			System.out.println("The number " + f + " works!");
		for (int j = 0; j < works.length; j++)
			works[j] = false;
	}
}[/code]

Output:

The number 0.25 works! The number 0.5 works! The number 1.0 works!

I divided by 100 to prevent this: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/5257166/java-floats-and-doubles-how-to-avoid-that-0-0-0-1-0-1-0-9000001

Read full topic

item.title: Find the magic number! (it's way to hard for me!)
item.dc:creator: @marc110 marc110
item.description:
@marc110 wrote:

Davidi2:

Well, then the only answer is 1… they don’t have any other factors in common. The first two have 3 in common, and the last two have 2/4/8 in common, but nothing else all 4 numbers share except 1. Unless you typed the numbers or question wrong too

i think the numbers are wrong or the question like this guy said . not all 4 numbers has any number in common

item.title: Find the magic number! (it's way to hard for me!)
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

I will write a simple script if the result can be a decimal number.

int getRandomNumber(){
return 7;
}

or
double getRandomDecimalNumber(){
return 1 / (Math.pow(2 ,getRandomNumber()));
}

I was a bit unsure about what number that should be a decimal number.

This makes no sense. It’s a pointless question if you can have decimals, unless this is like a comp sci class and you need to create a program. And yea, when you removed the part about it can have decimals, that made it sound like it had to be a whole number.

Well, then the only answer is 1… they don’t have any other factors in common. The first two have 3 in common, and the last two have 2/4/8 in common, but nothing else all 4 numbers share except 1. Unless you typed the numbers or question wrong too

item.title: Find the magic number! (it's way to hard for me!)
item.dc:creator: @eyeownyew Eyeownyew
item.description:
@eyeownyew wrote:

[code] double[] numbers = { 7104, 3087, 6208, 3496 };
boolean[] works = new boolean[numbers.length];

private void run() {
	for (int i = 0; i < 500; i++) {
		for (int j = 0; j < numbers.length; j++) {
			if (numbers[j] % i == 0)
				works[j] = true;
		}
		if (works[0] && works[1] && works[2] && works[3])
			System.out.println("The number " + i + " works!");
		for (int j = 0; j < works.length; j++)
			works[j] = false;
	}
}[/code]

Output:

The number 1 works!
There are no other solutions, David was right

Edit:[quote=“HcoJustin, post:6, topic:517443”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=635701.msg4286348#msg4286348 date=1366401037]
Well, then the only answer is 1… they don’t have any other factors in common. The first two have 3 in common, and the last two have 2/4/8 in common, but nothing else all 4 numbers share except 1. Unless you typed the numbers or question wrong too
[/quote]
It can have decimals in it… So we have to look past the GCD and just take random shots in the dark[/quote]
Wait what the love? If it can have decimals, it has literally infinite solutions

Read full topic
